member.name: T:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Features.ActivationDefinition
member.summary: The class provides data indicating requirements for a feature to be activated.
member.remarks: External code cannot inherit from this class, one way this is being prevented is by how is constructed. The class only has an internal constructor, while its inheritors must always only have private or internal constructors. This pattern makes it impossible to inherit from this type from outside of the assembly.

member.name: M:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.FeatureConnectionServiceManager.OnServiceDisposed(Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.FeatureService)
member.summary: Handles the event for all service instances owned by the current domain.
member.remarks: When a service is disposed from within the current domain instance the event handler is unregistered first, therefore this event handler is only raised on invalid operations inside the platform. Disposing a single service by bypassing the domain instance is illegal. The primary task of this event handler is to cause the domain to shut down silently.
member.param: The disposed service, expected to be part of the current domain.

member.name: M:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.FeatureService.AssertDisposed
member.summary: Asserts to not be called.
member.remarks:
Warning!
Do not remove or work around this assertion, it is an excellent indicator of something being wrong in any area of the code! In general you can very easily find the cause of a failing assertion by putting a breakpoint in or .
Working with disposed services is anyway not safe since it would cause resource leaks which remain unresolved until the platform is completely shut down, additionally it might also result in events being sent to potentially disposed features.
Another way to debug these exceptions is to add a as a class variable of , and initialize this variable when the method is called. Then place a breakpoint before the throw statement and use the debugger to read the variable. Having both the stack trace of the call to and of the call violating the flag (which is the call hitting the breakpoint) should enable you to find the cause of the issue.
member.exception: Thrown when the current service is disposed.

member.name: M:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.FeatureService.DoDispose
member.summary: When inherited, disposes all the service resources. After this method returns, will always throw an and this method won't ever be called again from the base class.

member.name: T:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.AdvancedGraphic
member.summary: The abstract class is the base class for any kind of graphic which is composed of multiple other graphics.

remarks.para: The class is designed so to be used as follows:
The method is the method where the inheritor receives an instance of and is expected to open the needed instance. The inheritor must NOT keep a reference to the service instance.
The method is then expected to draw all required graphics to the previously opened contexts. Prior to drawing, the affected contexts should always be cleared. is automatically called right after .
Any properties affecting the graphic appearance should be set using . The method calls the method if the given values are different.

member.name: T:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType
member.summary: The enum defines what a line or curve represents. This will affect the curve color and width.
member.remarks: should be used to represent the final modification and all the other curve types should be used only to augment the with additional helpful graphics in order to improve usability.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.GeometryPreview
member.summary: The curve is a representation of the final result after the modification. This could be for example an edge or a mid-line of a solid resulting from the modification.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.FixedGeometryPreview
member.summary: The curve is a representation of a fixed geometry part, being moved in the model.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaPreviewInside
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a preview of an extrema box during insertion. This part of the extrema box is inside some other object. (The inside / outside condition does not need to be perfectly solved to all neighbors, but can, for example, help visualize spatial relation to the nearest object face).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaPreviewOutside
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a preview of an extrema box during insertion. This part of the extrema box is outside some other object. (The inside / outside condition does not need to be perfectly solved to all neighbors, but can, for example, help visualize spatial relation to the nearest object face).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaPreviewOnFace
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a preview of an extrema box during insertion. This part of the extrema box is on the face of some other object. (The inside / outside condition does not need to be perfectly solved to all neighbors, but can, for example, help visualize spatial relation to the nearest object face).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaInside
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a of an extrema box in the model. This part of the extrema box is inside some other object. (The inside / outside condition does not need to be perfectly solved to all neighbors, but can, for example, help visualize spatial relation to the nearest object face).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaOutside
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a of an extrema box in the model. This part of the extrema box is outside some other object. (The inside / outside condition does not need to be perfectly solved to all neighbors, but can, for example, help visualize spatial relation to the nearest object face).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaOnFace
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a of an extrema box in the model. This part of the extrema box is on the face of some other object. (The inside / outside condition does not need to be perfectly solved to all neighbors, but can, for example, help visualize spatial relation to the nearest object face).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.ExtremaPreviewPlaneProjection
member.summary: The curve is a representation is a preview of an extrema box during modification. This part of the extrema box is the projection of the extrema box to a plane, which can be the position where the extreme box intersects with that plane.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.SolidEdge
member.summary: The curve is an existing edge on a solid.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.SymmetryIndicator
member.summary: The curve indicates symmetry. It should be drawn on the line of symmetry when the feature automatically keeps the part symmetric (even when the user modifies only one of the sides).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.CurveOnFace
member.summary: The curve represents the curve that follows the part face. One example would be the intersection line between two parts (e.g. a weld).

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.OffsetCurve
member.summary: The curve represents the offset from another curve or a face.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.OffsetCurveForDimensionAxisX
member.summary: The curve represents an for a which is aligned to the X-axis.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.OffsetCurveForDimensionAxisY
member.summary: The curve represents an for a which is aligned to the Y-axis.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.OffsetCurveForDimensionAxisZ
member.summary: The curve represents an for a which is aligned to the Z-axis.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.Dimension
member.summary: The curve represents a dimension.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.DimensionAxisX
member.summary: The curve represents a which is aligned to the X-axis.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.DimensionAxisY
member.summary: The curve represents a which is aligned to the Y-axis.

member.name: F:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.CurveType.DimensionAxisZ

member.name: M:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Graphics.GraphicsContextDrawer.AssertDisposed
member.summary: Asserts the flag to be false.
member.remarks: Warning! Do not remove or work around this assertion, it is an excellent indicator of something being wrong in another area of the code! In general you can very easily find the cause of a failing assertion by putting a breakpoint in . Working with disposed contexts would anyway not be safe since it would cause graphics to leak on the view until the view is entirely redrawn.
member.exception: Thrown when the current context is disposed.

member.name: M:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.HandleManipulator`2.AssertDisposed
member.summary: Asserts the property to be false.
member.remarks: Warning! Do not remove or work around this assertion, it is an excellent indicator of something being wrong in another area of the code! In general you can very easily find the cause of a failing assertion by putting a breakpoint in . Working with disposed handles would anyway not be safe since it would cause handles to leak until the platform is completely shut down, additionally it would also result in events being sent to (disposed) features whenever the handle is hit.
member.exception: Thrown when the current handle is disposed.

member.name: E:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.IHandleStateEvents.DeleteRequested
member.summary: Occurs on a delete request for the handle, the return value indicates whether the delete action should be committed or not.
member.remarks: If no event handler is attached, the delete action won't be committed. If the return value is true and the event handler already disposed the handle, no further actions are executed. Otherwise, the handle is deleted by the handle interactor.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether numeric input for spacing is enabled.
member.remarks: In order to handle any spacing input, and must be set. In order to handle partial spacing input is also required. Examples of partial spacing input are "*400" and "2*".

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.INumericInputConfiguration.OffsetDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction in which to apply offset inputs.
member.remarks: This value needs to be set in order to support the input of both absolute and relative offset values, and to support the input of any spacing input if is true.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.INumericInputConfiguration.OffsetAbsoluteReference
member.summary: Gets or sets the reference location for determining absolute offset locations.
member.remarks: This value needs to be set in order to support the input of relative offset values, and to support the input of any spacing input if is true.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.INumericInputConfiguration.SpacingAbsoluteReference
member.summary: Gets or sets the reference for determining the result of spacing input.
member.remarks: This value needs to be set in order to support the input of partial spacing data.

member.summary: The class provides configurable properties affecting the behavior of handles on numeric input.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.NumericInputConfiguration.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether numeric input is enabled.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.NumericInputConfiguration.EnabledOnHighlighted
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether numeric input is enabled when highlighted.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.NumericInputConfiguration.EnableSpacingInput
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether numeric input for spacing is enabled.
member.remarks: In order to handle any spacing input, must be set. In order to handle partial spacing input is also required. Examples of partial spacing input are "*400" and "2*".

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.NumericInputConfiguration.OffsetDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction in which to apply offset inputs.
member.remarks: This value needs to be set in order to support the input of both absolute and relative offset values, and to support the input of any spacing input if is true.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.NumericInputConfiguration.OffsetAbsoluteReference
member.summary: Gets or sets the reference location for determining absolute offset locations.
member.remarks: This value needs to be set in order to support the input of relative offset values, and to support the input of any spacing input if is true.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Interaction.NumericInputConfiguration.SpacingAbsoluteReference
member.summary: Gets or sets the reference for determining the result of spacing input.
member.remarks: This value needs to be set in order to support the input of partial spacing data.

member.name: T:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Manipulators.InteractiveTextManipulator
member.summary:
This class implements a manipulator that represents a text that can be clicked and then requests a value. The request is controlled by the property. Once a request has been done, the corresponding event is fired.
The manipulator is meant to be contained within a parent manipulator, which then can decide what to do with the request.
member.remarks: Once an event fires, it is recommended that the user (i.e. the entity processing the event) changes the property, so that the text value of the manipulator can change to represent a new value, if needed.

member.name: T:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Manipulators.InteractiveTextRequest
member.summary: Class to represent a user request for the interactive text manipulator. It is implemented as a tagged union, where the tag represents the request type that will be done by the manipulator, and the text value contains the text that will be displayed by the text handle.

member.name: P:Tekla.BIM.DirectManipulation.Services.Toleration.TolerationChangedEventArgs.Handled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the present state of the event handling. This flag indicates whether or not the required actions have been taken for the event and that e.g. object highlighting or other toleration related actions can be suppressed. When set to true, the event is still raised for all registered event handlers.
member.value: If setting, set to true if the event is to be marked handled; otherwise false. If reading this value, true indicates that either a class handler, or some instance handler along the route, has already marked this event handled. False indicates that no such handler has marked the event handled. The default value is false.
